data.title: Point Imperial
data.listingDescription: Grand Canyon Lodge, the visitor center and campground are CLOSED for the remainder of the 2025 season. The highest point on the rim of Grand Canyon at 8,803 feet (2,683 m), Point Imperial is also the most northern boundary of the park. Visitors have views of the Painted Desert and the eastern end of Grand Canyon. From here the canyon transforms from the narrow walls of Marble Canyon, visible as a winding gash, to a more open and dramatic "grand" canyon view.

images.altText: A prominent formation with a white rock spire against the backdrop of the red cliffs of Grand Canyon
images.title: Point Imperial
images.caption: Mount Hayden as seen from Point Imperial.

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the lodge, visitor center, campground and Bright Angel Point, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

The highest point on the rim of Grand Canyon at 8,803 feet (2,683 m), Point Imperial is also the most northern boundary of the park.

From here, visitors have views of the Painted Desert and the eastern end of Grand Canyon. It is from this area that the canyon transforms from the narrow walls of Marble Canyon, visible only as a winding gash, to a more open and dramatic "grand" canyon. Layers of red and black Precambrian rocks, not visible at Bright Angel Point, add contrast and color.

Part of the viewpoint is accessible for wheelchairs and strollers.
data.audioDescription: A D Stop 7, Point Imperial. 4 ¼ minutes. The road to Point Imperial leads north from the ‘Y’ nearly three miles (four and a half kilometers) to a one-way loop road at the point itself. At the far end of the loop road, to the right, a row of parallel car parking spaces faces a six-foot wide asphalt sidewalk. Larger recreational vehicles may parallel park at the left alongside a second sidewalk, beside a grove of trees with several picnic tables. Note there are vault toilets located at the far northern end of the picnic area. A wide concrete walkway leads to two pairs of gender-neutral, wheelchair accessible vault toilets at the left and right. Just beyond the open doorways to the toilets, note also there is a wildlife-proof garbage can, flanked by two recycling cans for plastic, glass, and aluminum. About two-thirds of the way around the parking lot loop to the right, opposite two wheelchair accessible parking spaces, a six-foot (two meter) wide asphalt path lined with small boulders leads east down a slight incline from the lot towards the point. At the head of the path to the left, a five-foot (one and a half meter) tall wooden sign stands before a roughly 30 foot (nine meter) wide dirt and gravel area under a stand of tall Ponderosa pine. Block capital letters read, “POINT IMPERIAL, ELV 8803” (2684 meters). About 30 feet straight ahead from the elevation sign, a three-foot tall wayside panel mounted on an angled, metal reading rail overlooks the rim to the east. Entitled, “Missing Layers,” it discusses why no dinosaur fossils have been unearthed in Grand Canyon. A description of this panel is included in the sub-script below. To the left of the wayside panel, a wooden bench overlooks the rim. Note there are no guardrails between the bench and rim. To the left of the bench, a three-foot tall wayside panel mounted on an angled, metal reading rail overlooks the rim. Entitled “Grand Canyon Vista: Highest Viewpoint,” it discusses the very different view of the rock layers here. A description of this panel is included in the sub-script below. About 30 feet to the right of the elevation sign, note a second wooden bench in an open, dirt and gravel area behind a low, half-log wooden bench closer to the rim. Note there are no guardrails here, either. Continuing down the wheelchair accessible asphalt path towards the point, it first curves slightly left, then turns sharply back right down a slightly steeper incline along the rim’s edge to a flight of concrete stairs with metal handrails on either side. Eleven stairs lead halfway down to a concrete landing, followed by eleven more stairs to a concrete landing at the bottom of the staircase. Continuing forward from the landing, move onto the rough, rocky terrain of the roughly 30 foot long by 10 foot wide (nine by three meter) lookout area at Point Imperial. Note the entire area is surrounded by four-foot tall metal railings. From here at the most northern boundary of the park, visitors take in panoramic views of the Painted Desert and the eastern end of Grand Canyon and Vermilion Cliffs beyond. The canyon transforms from the narrow walls of Marble Canyon to a more open and dramatic "grand" canyon. Layers of red and black Precambrian rocks add contrast and color. Note at the far northern end of the parking lot, a wooden sign to the right of a dirt and gravel trail identifies the Point Imperial trail (5.4 miles roundtrip; 8.7 kilometers) that ends at the north park boundary. A second, smaller wooden sign shows the distances to the Saddle Mountain Trail (2.2 miles, 3.5 kilometers), and the Nankoweap Trail (5.2 miles, 8.4 kilometers). Note also at the far southern end of the lot, a 15-foot (five meter) wide, stone staircase leads down one step to a stone landing, then down three more stone steps to a dirt and gravel area and the beginning of the unpaved Ken Patrick Trail in a grove of trees. The 9.8 mile (15.8 kilometer) trail winds through the forest and along the rim to the North Kaibab Trail parking area. Sub-Script Missing Layers Wayside Panel A panoramic color vista of the canyon from Point Imperial fills the face of the panel. The Vermillion and Echo Cliffs are just visible far off in the distance, with the tall Kaibab limestone cliffs close in the foreground. Entitled “Missing Layers,” words at the top left read: In the distant view you can see the Mesozoic rocks of the Vermilion and Echo cliffs, where the nearest dinosaur fossils are found. No dinosaur fossils have been unearthed in Grand Canyon, but that does not mean dinosaurs never roamed here. Mesozoic rock layers—a mile (1.6 km) thick—once covered the canyon’s Kaibab Limestone layer, the rock where you are standing. When the Kaibab Plateau rose up 70–40 million years ago, the soft overlaying Mesozoic rock cracked, broke, and eroded away. Like hosing mud from a cement driveway, the Mesozoic rock vanished from the hard-surfaced Kaibab Limestone, washing away all evidence of dinosaurs. At the top right, additional red cliffs shown in two small inset color photographs are identified as Zion and Glen Canyon. A caption above reads: North of the Vermilion Cliffs in Utah are Zion, Capitol Reef, Glen Canyon, and Arches national park sites, all carved from Mesozoic rocks. At the lower right, a green, circular Junior Ranger icon appears over an inset color photograph of a young boy facing us with his arms outstretched to the sides. Entitled, “Arms Span Time,” words next to a short, vertical white line by his fingertips at the left read, “Earth Forms.” Moving right, words next to a short, vertical white line by his right shoulder read, “Oldest Grand Canyon rocks.” By his thumb at the right, “Youngest Grand Canyon rocks.” At the base of his fingers, “Age of dinosaurs.” And finally by his fingertips at the far right, “Grand Canyon carved,” and “Today.” Grand Canyon Vista: Highest Viewpoint Wayside Panel A panoramic, labeled color vista of the canyon from this spot at Point Imperial fills the face of the panel. At the left there is the Marble Platform, Nankoweap Mesa, and the Colorado River (hidden), with the Supergroup rocks in the left foreground. The Desert Façade appears at the center left, and the much closer, pyramid-shaped Mt. Hayden at the right. Text at the top reads: As you look east from Point Imperial’s vista, you command the highest viewpoint in the park, at 8,803 feet (2,684 m). The view is very different here. There is no visible basement rock in the rock layers—the river has not cut that deeply yet. Prominent in the middle view are the Supergroup rocks, the middle rock layers of the canyon, often absent or obscured. The distant Marble Platform is a 2,700 foot (820 m) step down from Point Imperial. Though not visible in the view, as the raven flies, you are nearly seven miles (11 km) removed from the Colorado River. The river meanders its course more than a mile (1.6 km) below this elevation. At the lower right, a green, circular Junior Ranger icon appears over an inset color photograph of the Washington Monument and Reflecting Pool. Text reads: Highest Vista, Biggest Drop You are at the highest viewpoint looking at the deepest view. Directly east is Nankoweap Mesa—the mesa topped with Limestone west of the Desert Facade. Behind this mesa is the river, some 6,000 feet (1,830 m) below us here – translated in Washington Monuments: that is 10 of them stacked end to end.

data.title: Powell Monument
data.listingDescription: The park's largest monument (in size) is found here. Completed in 1915 to honor Major John Wesley Powell and his group—the first to 'run' the Colorado River in Grand Canyon, this area also bore witness to the park's formal dedication in 1920.

images.altText: A large dark brown bronze plaque rests in a large block of white limestone.
images.title: Powell Monument
images.caption: A memorial for the men who dared to dive into the Great Unknown

data.bodyText:
The park's largest monument (in size) is found here. Completed in 1915 to honor Major John Wesley Powell and his group—the first to 'run' the Colorado River in Grand Canyon, this area also bore witness to the park's formal dedication in 1920.

The plaque at the top of the stairs commemorates Powell, the men who joined him on this two trips down the Green and Colorado Rivers through the canyon, and both the 50th and 75th anniversaries of Grand Canyon National Park.
data.audioDescription: Two openings in the low 2-foot (60 cm) high limestone wall lead north away from the sidewalk at the shuttle bus stop, two, 6-foot (2 m) wide asphalt-paved paths are lined with low, irregular stones. One path leads down a set of three stone steps. The more western path leads to a wheelchair accessible ramp. The two paths converge about 30 feet (9 m) along. Move 200 feet (60 m) forward on the path along the narrow point to a 12-foot (3.5 m) tall by 20-foot (6 m) wide limestone memorial—a Mayan-style truncated pyramid with a central staircase. Nearby, a photograph at the top right of a 3-foot (1 m) tall angled metal wayside panel, shows a bearded man in the canyon, next to an etching depicting long wooden boats running the rapids. Text on the panel reads: "Early Explorer This monument honors Major John Wesley Powell, the leader of the first documented expedition through Grand Canyon. Imagine entering the depths of Grand Canyon down a roaring, not-yet-charted river, not knowing whether you will emerge. Because Powell's first expedition in 1869 was more survival than science, he led a second in 1871-1872, which gave America its first geologic glimpse of the canyon. Powell's crew prepares to shove off at Green River, Wyoming on their 1871-1872 expedition." Two 3-foot (1 m) wide by 3-foot (1 m) tall stone railings line either side of the central 8-foot (2.4 m) wide, 15-step stone staircase of the monument, leading up to a 10x12-foot (3x4-meter) platform. Text below an image of a man with thinning hair and a long, bushy beard, cast into the center of a 6-foot (2 m) wide by 4-foot (1.2 m) tall metal plaque at the back of the landing, reads: "Erected by the Congress of the United States to Major John Wesley Powell first explorer of the Grand Canyon who descended the river with his party in row boats traversing the gorge beneath this point August 17, 1869 and again September 1, 1872." Two circular metal plaques on the left face of the monument commemorate the 50th and 75th anniversaries of Grand Canyon National Park. A similar plaque on the right face commemorates the 100th anniversary of the Powell expedition in 1969. A portrait of a young, bearded man fills the center. The asphalt path continues around both sides of the monument and converges 30 feet (9 m) behind the structure. Two wooden benches sit to the left of each path, at the back of a 20-foot (6 m) wide open viewing area located on the point itself. Note there are no railings here, the viewing platform being ringed only by a series of large stones.

data.title: Powell Point Bus Stop - Hermits Rest (Red) Route
data.listingDescription: NO BUS SERVICE during December, January and February. While a fine view of Grand Canyon is visible directly after stepping off the shuttle bus, a short, easy walk along the paved path out to the viewpoint is rewarded with even more excellent views and access to the Powell Memorial.

images.altText: a white and green bus unloading passengers by a low rock wall with the canyon landscape beyond.
images.title: Powell Point shuttle stop
images.caption: The approach to Powell Point is a bit exposed, but it offers a huge view as a reward.

data.bodyText:
NOT IN SERVICE DURING THE WINTER

Hermit Road is open to private vehicles (under 22 feet) during the months of December, January and Februay, when there is no bus service.

  • Between March 1, and November 30, Hermit Road can only be accessed by the free Hermits Rest (Red) Route shuttle bus, on foot, bicycle, or by commercial tour.


TWO WAY STOP - Outbound to Hermits Rest — Inbound to the Village

Nearby:

While a fine view of Grand Canyon is visible directly after stepping off the shuttle bus, a short, easy walk along the paved path out to the viewpoint is rewarded with even more excellent views and access to the Powell Memorial.

This large stone monument commemorates the 1869 Powell Expedition, the first known European American explorers to map the river's course by boat, traveling the Green and Colorado Rivers from Wyoming all the way through Grand Canyon.

Powell Point is the first of the three two-way shuttle stops along the Hermit Road. From here, one may board an outbound shuttle bus heading farther west to Hermits Rest, or inbound (east), back to Grand Canyon Village. 

Hermits Rest (Red) Route 

Tentative Spring 2026 Schedule - Starting March 1
80 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)
 
  • First bus leaves Hermit Transfer Station at 8:00 am. 
  • Buses run every 10-15 minutes.
  • Last bus - one hour after sunset.
  • Be at a bus stop 30 minutes after sunset

Route Information

OUTBOUND and INBOUND stop
From the Powell Point shuttle stop, one can board buses heading both outbound (west), towards Hermits Rest, and inbound (east), returning to the Village. From here, outbound buses stop at the following locations before returning to Powell Point and then Grand Canyon Village:

  • Hopi Point
  • Mohave Point (Outbound and Inbound)
  • The Abyss
  • Monument Creek Vista
  • Pima Point (Outbound and Inbound)
  • Hermits Rest
  • Pima Point (Inbound)
  • Mohave Point (Inbound)
  • Powell Point (Inbound)
  • Village Route Transfer

From here at Powell Point, eastbound buses return directly to the Hermit Road/Village Route Transfer station.

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No eating or open drink containers.  
  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).  
  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.  
  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.  
  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.  
  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.

data.title: Ranger Operations
data.listingDescription: Listed as a National Historic Landmark, this stone and wood building was built in 1929 to replace the first park headquarters as the historic village and Grand Canyon National Park grew over the years. Today, it serves as the park's law enforcement center and is not open to the public.

images.altText: A two story wood and stone building with steps and an USA flag out front
images.title: Ranger Ops
images.caption: In the heart of the village this beautiful building has seen the canyon grow over the years.

data.bodyText:
This building serves as the park's law enforcement center and is not open to the public. If you have an medical or law enforcement emergency please call 9-1-1.

Listed as a National Historic Landmark, this stone and wood building was built in 1929 to replace the first park headquarters as the historic village and Grand Canyon National Park grew over the years. Eventually the park headquarters would be moved one mile east to a new building constructed during the mission 66 era of park development. 

Like most of the buildings in the Grand Canyon Historic Village this building's use has varied and shifted over the years as first the village and then the park continued to grow. As the canyon grew in popularity and year after year saw increases to park visitation the services the National Park Service and its partners have provided have had to grow and the Village was expanded to include the Market Plaza and Grand Canyon Visitor Center Plaza.

Some buildings have been lost over the years, like the gas station that used to sit where the parking lot now is, while others have found new purpose. How would you change or adapt to help protect something you loved?

Today, this building serves as the park's law enforcement center and is not open to the public. If you have an medical or law enforcement emergency please call 9-1-1.
data.audioDescription: No public services

data.title: Rapid Events
data.listingDescription: Located at Pima Point, along Hermit Road, this wayside overlooks Granite Rapids and describes a flash flood event on July 27, 1984, that moved a lot of rocks and debris down a side canyon and into the Colorado River, markedly increasing the size of the rapid.

images.altText: A wayside on the edge of Grand Canyon
images.title: Rapid events
images.caption: One of the best views of the Colorado River is visible from this sign.

data.bodyText:
Located at Pima Point, along Hermit Road, this wayside overlooks Granite Rapids and describes a flash flood event on July 27, 1984, that moved a lot of rocks and debris down a side canyon and into the Colorado River, markedly increasing the size of the rapid. 

This may not be the biggest view of the river itself, but it is one of the best views of major rapid within Grand Canyon from the canyon's rim. Here on a quiet day you can even hear the distant roar of white water. If we can hear it over three miles away through dead space, how loud must it be at the river itself?
data.audioDescription:
From the shuttle bus stop, move 80 feet (24 m) east along a two-foot (60 cm) high stone wall lining the inside of the asphalt sidewalk to a three-foot (1 m) wide opening on your left. Move away from the road down three stone steps onto another asphalt sidewalk, and proceed 20 feet (6 m) forward to a vast overlook lined with a four-foot (1.2 m) tall metal railing running left-to-right along the edge of the canyon.
At the northernmost corner of a wide promontory, Pima Point provides a vista of over 40 miles (64 km) along Grand Canyon, from Bright Angel Canyon in the east all the way west to Powell Plateau and the Great Scenic Divide. Grand Canyon rock layers are on full display from the two-billion-year-old Vishnu Schist at the bottom of the canyon up through the various layers of sandstone, shale, and limestone all the way up to the rim.
Far below, the Colorado River is visible in several places as it winds through deep gorges, including Granite Rapids to the east. Stand still, be quiet, close your eyes. Can you hear the distant roar of the rapids, or the wing beat of a passing raven?
Various sections of the Hermit Trail are in view, zigzagging down through rocky buttes, as are the meandering paths of numerous side creeks lined with green vegetation. Debris flows appear in several places on the faces of the canyon walls, evidence of side washes where raging water rushed over cliff edges, triggering avalanches of rock, mud, water, and depositing boulders in their wake, and sometimes all the way into the river below.

data.title: Red Horse/Bright Angel Cabin
data.listingDescription: This log cabin was originally built in 1888. It was used as a stage stop, hotel, post office, and after extensive restoration, it has become two rooms of the Bright Angel Lodge.

images.altText: A small cabin with orangish red paint, a red door, and a brown single roof with a stone chimney.
images.title: Red Horse Inn
images.caption: Now a room for rent, this cabin has a grand history

data.bodyText:
This log cabin was originally built in 1888 and used to be located 25 miles south of Grand Canyon, at Red Horse. In 1902, Ralph Cameron had it moved to its present site, where, with the addition of a porch and a second story, it became known as the Cameron Hotel. From 1910 to 1935, this building housed the United States Post Office for the local Grand Canyon community. Eventually, after shifting from owner to owner it underwent extensive restoration and became two rooms of the Bright Angel Lodge.

A small plaque next to the door commemorate's the buildings role in Grand Canyon History. 

As this is an active room within the Bright Angel Lodge complex please respect the privacy of the visitors who may be inside.
data.audioDescription: At the back of the wide Bright Angel Trail plaza, southeast of the restrooms, stands a red, one-story log cabin. The 25x30-foot (8x9 m) structure has a gable, wood shingle roof with exposed rafters, log walls with dovetail corners, and a stone foundation and chimney. A bronze plaque to the left of the sherbet green wood door reads: "Bright Angel Cabin 88 & 89, Constructed in the 1890s Originally this building stood at Red Horse, 25 miles south of the Grand Canyon, where it was possibly used as one of the stage stops between Grand Canyon and Flagstaff. In 1902, Ralph Cameron had it moved to its present site, where, with the addition of a porch and a second story, it became known as the Cameron Hotel. From 1910 to 1935, this building housed the United States Post Office. "Eventually, after extensive restoration, it became two rooms of the Bright Angel Lodge.

data.title: Revealing Features
data.listingDescription: This wayside describes several of the unique features in the design of the Desert View Watchtower and expounds on Mary Colter's attention to detail. What details of the tower do you notice? What shapes and patterns do you see? Mary Colter built for the present and future while honoring the local cultures of the past. If you were to build something who, or what, would you look to for inspiration?

images.altText: A wayside with a picture of the watchtower and text
images.title: Revealing Features
images.caption: There are even more details Colter included in the tower, what do you see?

data.bodyText:
This wayside describes several of the unique features in the design of the Desert View Watchtower and expounds on Mary Colter's attention to detail. What details of the tower do you notice? What shapes and patterns do you see?

Mary Colter built for the present and future, while honoring the local cultures of the past. If you were to build something who, or what, would you look to for inspiration?
data.audioDescription: As you approach the Desert View Watchtower, just before the path turns left toward a doorway at the base of the tower into the circular kiva, a color photograph of the Desert View Watchtower fills a 3-foot (1 m) tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text at the top right reads: "Revealing Features Mary Colter's attention to detail is reflected in every element of the Desert View Watchtower. Each rock and painted wall was intended to convey meaning. Colter used ornamental details, seeming haphazardly, to create an added charm of the unexpected. Find triangular and diamond patterned rocks, horizontal bands of different sizes, and actual petroglyphs with pecked designs. The tower features T-shaped doors and tapered windows like buildings hundreds of years old. Colter used uneven masonry surfaces to "create shadow and give more vigor to the walls." At the bottom left of the panel, text continues: "Stories Preserved in Stone Many ideas from Colter's research trips emerge in this architectural masterpiece. Climb the 85 steps and allow the artists' and masons' details to reveal themselves." The first of 4 black-and-white photographs to the right shows a man wearing jeans, a long-sleeve white shirt, and a headband standing next to a T-shaped stone door from Chaco Culture National Historical Park, followed by a close-up of diamond-patterned rocks from the same location. The next picture of petroglyphs from the Painted Desert shows various animal and human figures and a sun spirit. The last photograph shows a couple perpendicular stone walls with intermingled rows of roughly rectangular- and triangular-shaped stones—examples of ornamental masonry from Wupatki National Monument.

data.title: Shoshone Point Parking Area
data.listingDescription: An unsigned dirt parking area is all that marks the trail out to Shoshone Point. An easy one-mile walk along an old dirt road takes one through ponderosa forest, which eventually transitions to a pinyon-juniper woodland near the rim of the canyon.

images.altText: An open dirt parking lot with vehicles beneath pine trees.
images.caption: Park your car at Shoshone Point dirt parking lot and walk one mile to the viewpoint

data.bodyText:
An unsigned dirt parking area is all that marks the trail out to Shoshone Point. An easy one-mile walk along an old dirt road takes one through ponderosa forest, which eventually transitions to a pinyon-juniper woodland near the rim of the canyon. A relatively quiet viewpoint along the rim of the canyon facing north-northeast awaits at the end of the walk.

Shoshone Point is the only area within the park that can be reserved for private events and gatherings. Please respect the use of the site for those who have gone through the reservation and permitting process. If the gate blocking the use of the road/trail is open or unlocked, please reconsider visiting the site.

For those not reserving this area for an event, it is a short 2-mile round trip hike that follows a dirt road out to the rim of the Grand Canyon for views toward the Desert View Watchtower and across the canyon to the North Rim. 

Note: In spring the road tends to be very muddy as the snow thaws on the canyon rim. Please stick to the road and be prepared for the conditions of the season. 

Group Events

The park offers this area for groups wishing to host a wedding, celebrate a birthday, conduct a memorial service, hold a family reunion, or a similar event. The site features a covered pavilion, picnic tables, grills, trash cans, and a vault toilet. There is no water or electricity. An unimproved dirt road leads to this isolated area.

You may obtain a permit for a reservation no earlier than one year prior to the requested date on a first come, first-served basis. To obtain a permit, visit: http://www.nps.gov/grca/parkmgmt/sup.htm.

What's in a name?

Shoshone Point is named after the Shoshone tribe, a North American Indian group that occupied a territory that is now southeastern California, across central and eastern Nevada and northwestern Utah into southern Idaho and western Wyoming. Today, the Shoshone still live on reservations throughout the west in the states or Idaho, Wyoming, Utah, and Nevada.
data.audioDescription: A little over a mile (1.6 km) east of Yaki Point Road, an unsigned turn-off on the north side of Desert View Drive leads to a small parking lot in the forest. A locked gate at the north end of the lot limits access to an unpaved, single lane road that leads one mile (1.6 km) through the forest to Shoshone Point. Smell the air. A prescribed fire once burned here. The flames licked and blackened the trunks and branches of the ponderosa pine trees of this forest, completely engulfing some, and felling others. New grasses and pine saplings sprout up through the bed of pine needles covering the ground. Touch the five to nine inch (12 to 23 cm) long needles, bound together in bundles of three. Notice the different color bark of the trees. Young trees have rough black bark, while older trees have deep orange-brown bark. About 50 feet (15 m) back from the road and 25 feet (8 m) west of the parking lot stands an 80-foot (24 m) tall double-trunk ponderosa pine tree with a blackened trunk. Move to this tree, being mindful of the uneven ground and shallow trench cut into the soil. Touch the thick, rough bark of this mature tree. Find a deep fissure in the bark, and put your nose into it to smell the sweet aromas of vanilla and butterscotch.

data.title: Shrine of the Ages
data.listingDescription: Shrine of the Ages is a multi-purpose building used by the National Park Service, and community groups. It can be rented for private functions, including weddings. Located near Market Plaza, it is half-way between the Visitor Center, and the Village Historic District. Parking is on the west end of Parking Lot A. The auditorium is within walking distance of Market Plaza, Mather Campground, Trailer Village, and Yavapai Lodge. Eastbound and westbound village shuttles stop here.

images.altText: A modern 2 story building with stone walls and large wooden entryway arches and large glass windows
images.title: Shrine of the Ages side entrance
images.caption: The west-facing side entrance to Shrine of the Ages Auditorium

data.bodyText:
Shrine of the Ages is a multi-purpose building used by the National Park Service, Grand Canyon Conservancy, and community groups. It can also be rented for private functions, including family gatherings and wedding ceremonies, with an application for a Special Use Permit.

Parking is on the west end of Parking Lot A. Shrine of the Ages is within walking distance of Market Plaza, Mather Campground, Trailer Village RV Campground, and Yavapai Lodge. The Village (Blue) Route shuttle has designated stops here. Eastbound (to the Visitor Center) and westbound (to the Village Historic District).

Planning to host or attend an event at the Shrine? Additional information is located on the Grand Canyon Shrine of Ages webpage.

Special events, such as concerts, symposia or cultural presentations take place in the auditorium. Activities include: park ranger programs, guest speakers, visiting artists, musicians, or even students from Grand Canyon School who present their own programs to the community and park visitors.

The Grand Canyon Music Festival has taken place here in the Shrine, every year for 42 years, during August and September. 

When you are visiting the park, ask at the Visitor Center to see if programs are being offered during your stay, or view the park's Digital Calendar for current schedules.  

Religious Services

Religious services are offered in Shrine if the Ages Auditorium, and the surrounding community. Current schedules are posted at Mather Campground (near the check-in station), the information kiosk near the U.S Post Office in Market Plaza, the Visitor Center, and Verkamp's Visitor Center in the Village Historic District.

History

Although the idea for an interfaith chapel at Grand Canyon was proposed as early as 1917, it was not until 1952 that the Shrine of the Ages Chapel Corporation was formed, plans drawn up, and fundraising started. Representatives from Catholic, Jewish, and Protestant services comprised the Corporation. The National Park Service approved it because it offered the opportunity for all religious faiths to have a place of worship. The idea was to build a permanent building near a site on the canyon rim already used for services, including a very popular Easter Sunrise service.

Harold E. Wagoner, a member of the board of directors of the Church Architectural Guild of America, was selected as architect. Working within National Park Service guidelines to respect the natural environment and American Indian culture, he designed a structure that reflected the architectural style of a kiva, a place of worship used by native people in the Southwest. This design worked well since the National Park Service also required that no towers or specific religious symbols be used.

Because the initial building site was on the rim of the canyon just west of today's Hermits Rest Route (red) shuttle stop, plans called for the main auditorium to have a sweeping canyon view from a multi-story, curved window placed behind the altar. A special hydraulic lift would raise and lower at least three different altar configurations for Jewish, Catholic, and Protestant services. An organ placed on a small balcony, with wind chests and pipes located at different sections of the main chapel, would provide stereophonic sound effects.

Even as fundraising efforts reached around the world, questions about whether the rim was an appropriate location for the structure resulted in delays. Some even argued that the building only remotely resembled a kiva, instead looking more like a huge spacecraft perched on the canyon rim. Donations were never quite enough to realize Wagoner's plans, and federal funding became involved. The building was ultimately redesigned and relocated away from the edge of the canyon. An appropriate site was chosen next to the existing Grand Canyon Pioneer Cemetery, and Shrine of the Ages was completed by 1970.

The National Park Service took over ownership of the building in 1975, along with all maintenance, operational, and administrative duties.
data.audioDescription: The Shrine of the Ages is a one-story building with limestone rubble walls that rise up and away from a central entranceway filled with three 20-foot (6 m) tall by 30-foot (9 m) wide towering T-shaped wooden arches. A couple ponderosa pine trees grow in the outdoor courtyard between the arches. Inside, a 250-plus seat auditorium with a large, multi-paned trapezoidal window wall is used by the National Park Service, Grand Canyon Conservancy, and others, and can also be rented for private functions. In the winter months, the nightly Evening Program is held inside the Shrine of the Ages, offering the opportunity to learn about a variety of Grand Canyon resources. Park rangers may discuss geology, human history, wildlife, the night sky, water resources, rock art, canyon hiking, and more. Special events, such as concerts or demonstrations, may take the place of a park ranger program allowing visiting artists, musicians, or students opportunities to present programs to the community and the general public.

quickFacts.value: Near Park Headquarters and Market Plaza
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Shrine of the Ages - Westbound Bus Stop - Village (Blue) Route
data.listingDescription: If you park in lot "A" by Shrine of the Ages, boarding the bus at this stop, will take you to the Village Historic District. Shrine of the Ages is a community auditorium used for religious services, ranger programs, and special events. At the opposite end of Lot A from this bus stop is Park Headquarters. At this time, Park Headquarters is closed to the public, however, trip planning information is displayed on signs in front of the building. Visit link for the schedule.

images.altText: A simple open air shelter provides shade for wooden benches at a bus stop
images.title: Shrine of ages westbound
images.caption: From Shrine of the Ages and Parking Lot A, buses travel west to the Village Historic District

data.bodyText:
Nearby:

  • Parking Lot A (131 spaces - No RV Parking)
  • Shrine of the Ages Auditorium
  • Park Headquarters
  • McKee Amphitheater (evening programs)
  • Spur Trail to Canyon Rim (0.4 mile (0.6 km)

This bus stop provides westbound shuttle service to the Village Historic District for visitors parked here —in Parking Lot A, a long, narrow lot with 131 spaces and centrally located. 

Shrine of the Ages, a community auditorium, is used for religious services, ranger programs, and occasional special events. 

At the opposite end of Lot A from from this bus stop is Park Headquarters. At this time, Park Headquarters is closed to the public, however, trip planning information is displayed on signs in front of the building.

On the west side of Park Headquarters, a paved 0.4 mile (0.6 km) spur trail leads to the canyon rim, connecting to the Canyon Rim Trail halfway between Yavapai Geology Museum and the Village Historic District. From the junction, turning left (west), is a 0.6 mile (0.9 km) walk to the village, or turning right (east) is 0.7 mile (1.13 km) walk to Yavapai Geology Museum. 

The spur trail also leads to McKee Amphitheater, where evening ranger programs are held during summer months. The amphitheater is immediately north of Park Headquaters, just a few minutes walk along the spur trail. Many visitors park here in Lot A to attend the evening programs. 

From this shuttle stop, the Village (Blue) Route bus continues west to the Train Depot, El Tovar Hotel, Bright Angel Lodge, and the Hermit (Red) Route Transfer stop before looping east and returning to the campgrounds, Market Plaza and Grand Canyon Visitor Center.

December 1, 2025, through February 28, 2026
50 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)

First bus at 8:00 am — the last bus is at 8:00 pm.

data.bodyText:

Just a 9-minute ride from the Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal, this shuttle stop is the easiest way to access the South Kaibab Trail. Running from dawn to dusk year-round, the bus will drop you off next to the water filling station and vault toilets at the trailhead.

Parking at the Visitor Center and taking this bus is recommended because private vehicle parking is not permitted at South Kaibab Trailhead.

The start of South Kaibab Trail and the rim of Grand Canyon are a short walk from here. Hikers interested in the following day hike destinations should take this bus. Bring your own water and snacks because no water is available on South Kaibab Trail. 

  • Ooh Aah Point — round trip: 1.8 miles/ 2.9 km — 600 ft/ 182 m below trailhead
  • Cedar Ridge — round trip: 3 miles/ 4.8 km — 1140 ft/ 347 m below trailhead
  • Skelleton Point — round trip: 6 miles/ 9.5 km — 2060 ft/ 627 m below trailhead

This shuttle stop is located at the eastern end of the paved Canyon Rim Trail. From here, you can walk west along the rim trail, a level footpath with scenic views, and return to the Visitor Center and Mather Point. Bicycles may also travel on this trail, west from here, but only as far as the Visitor Center..

data.audioDescription: Next to the 40-foot long South Kaibab Trailhead shuttle bus stop, a line of three-foot (1 m) tall limestone boulders line a four-foot (1.2 m) wide concrete sidewalk. There is a water filling station to the right about 10 feet (3 m) along the asphalt path leading from the bus stop to the trailhead. The water filling station is within a square enclosure surrounded by a chain link fence to prevent altercations between people and wildlife. Thirty feet to the right of the water station, a few picnic tables sit in a small clearing behind the boulders. To the right of the shuttle bus stop at the far end of the sidewalk are some vault toilets. Move north along the eight-foot wide asphalt trail 40 feet (12 m) to where the path turns right, and continue forward to a vertical wayside panel at the right opposite the trailhead. At the top left of the panel, a black and red circle surrounds a black-and-white image of Grand Canyon with large white letters urging you to, "Hike Smart." Text reads: "Welcome to South Kaibab Trail. This magnificent Grand Canyon is a vast and harsh wilderness demanding respect. Do You Have a Realistic Plan? Grand Canyon National Park assists more than 600 hikers during the hot summer months and helicopter rescues an additional 150 people...You are responsible for your safety and the safety of your friends and family. Rescue is not a guarantee. Have You Checked the Weather? Summer temperatures in the shade reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (40 degrees Celsius) below Skeleton Point and 115 degrees Fahrenheit (46 degrees Celsius) at Phantom Ranch. In winter, temperatures drop below freezing with steep, icy trails requiring shoe traction devices." At the upper right, a map of the trail shows distances and elevations. Text continues: "How Much Food and Water Should You Bring? Your body needs energy - balancing proper nutrition and hydration are critical to your hiking success...To the right, a list of standard trail courtesy items appear." At the bottom left, the panel states: "Never approach, touch, or feed any animal. It is dangerous...and illegal to do so. Pets are not allowed on the trails. If you wish to take a service animal with you, please check in at the Backcountry Information Center."

data.title: Stephen Mather Plaque (Mather Point)
data.listingDescription: On the way out to Mather Point, at the top right of the stairs leading down to the overlook, a plaque is mounted honoring the man for which the viewpoint is named. A 30-inch (76 cm) wide by three-foot (1 m) tall bronze plaque set into the face of a triangular limestone boulder shows the bust of a clean-shaven man in a suit and tie in profile at the right. Stephen Tyng Mather was one of the founding fathers of the National Park Service and its first director, and his contributions and impact towards the preservation and creation of so many natural, historical, and cultural treasures are inestimable.

images.altText: A rectangular metal plaque is mounted on a rough, uncut boulder of white limestone. Several more boulders litter the ground behind the one with the plaque. To the right of the plaque, a concrete walkway and series of steps lead down to a viewpoint looking out at the Grand Canyon landscape. Several people are standing or walking on the walkway and down the steps.
images.caption: Learn about the first National Park Service director Stephen Mather at Mather Point.

data.bodyText: On the way out to Mather Point, at the top right of the stairs leading down to the overlook, a plaque is mounted honoring the man for which the viewpoint is named. A 30-inch (76 cm) wide by three-foot (1 m) tall bronze plaque set into the face of a triangular limestone boulder shows the bust of a clean-shaven man in a suit and tie in profile at the right. Stephen Tyng Mather was one of the founding fathers of the National Park Service and its first director, and his contributions and impact towards the preservation and creation of so many natural, historical, and cultural treasures are inestimable.
data.audioDescription:
At the top right of the stairs leading down to the overlook at Mather Point, a 30-inch (76 cm) wide by three-foot (1 m) tall bronze plaque set into the face of a triangular limestone boulder shows the bust of a clean-shaven man in a suit and tie in profile at the right. He looks left to a tall stand of trees in a forest. High peaks of faraway mountains fill the middle space of the plaque.
Words at the top right read:
"Stephen Tyng Mather, July 4 1867, January 22, 1930."
A caption at the bottom of the plaque reads:
"He laid the foundation of the National Park Service defining and establishing the policies under which its areas shall be developed and conserved unimpaired for future generations. There will never come an end to the good that he has done.
Touch the plaque to feel the man's features, the trees and mountains in the background, and the boulder behind it."

data.title: Stone Corral and Mule Power Exhibit
data.listingDescription: This simple stone corral marks the beginning of the longest running tour operation in Grand Canyon history, the mule rides of Grand Canyon.

images.altText: A tilted interpretive exhibit board mounted in a metal frame supported by two metal posts stands next to a low, circular rock wall. Large black letters at the top of the board read "Mule Power". Taller rock pillars spaced at regular intervals along the wall support a thick metal railing which runs the entire way around the circle. In the middle of the circle is an open area covered in a thick layer of soft dirt. At the far side of this enclosure, there is a gap in the wall several feet wide.
images.caption: The mule corral at the Bright Angel Trailhead provides a temporary staging area for mules preparing to descend the trail into the canyon.

data.bodyText:
Most of the day this simple small corral sits empty, but stop by early in the morning and you'll have a chance to see the chaos of wranglers, mules, and eager mule riders as everyone gets ready for a once in a lifetime trip into the depths of Grand Canyon for an overnight stay at Phantom Ranch.

This staging area gives the wranglers a chance to meet the people they will be guiding into the canyon, fit riders to mules, adjust tackle, and one last chance for the eager riders to consider the wisdom in the long, arduous trip they are about to take. Once everything is ready they'll start the long windy path down the Bright Angel Canyon and trail to the Colorado River and the overnight lodging at Phantom Ranch. 

Start times will vary by the time of year, shifting with sunrise and sunset, and to avoid the heat of the canyon during the summer, but as long as there are riders the mules will go down every day, all year long.
data.audioDescription: On the east side of the mule corral on the Bright Angel trailhead plaza, a color photograph on a three-foot (1 m) tall angled metal wayside panel shows a cowboy standing in front of a line of eight mules with large packs strapped to their backs. The walls of the canyon rise behind them. Text at the top left reads: "Mule Power At Grand Canyon you can fill your senses with mules. You can smell them, hear their brays, see them snake down trails like trains, feel them as you sway on their saddled backs, and even taste their dust as they pass you on the trail. A cross between a male donkey and a female horse, mules are sensitive spirits in robust bodies. Grand Canyon is one of the few remaining places in the United States where mules are a common sight. Once prevalent on American farms, they are now largely replaced by tractors and trucks. At Grand Canyon, they excel at the jobs they are bred for: pack work and riding." Text at the lower left continues: "For more than a century, mules have carried almost everything imaginable in and out of Grand Canyon. With only trails through the wilderness below the rim, the mules will likely work for a long time." A quote at the top center by Theodore H. Savory from Scientific American reads: "The mule...is courageous and intelligent, hard of hide, sure of foot, sound of constitution and able to resist changes in climate and withstand thirst and hunger better than the horse." A green circle in the upper right-hand corner surrounds a park ranger hat with the words, "Junior Ranger." Three figures in silhouette do the biological math showing how a female horse plus a male donkey equals a mule. Text continues: "When a female horse is bred with a male donkey the offspring is a mule. The donkey gives the mule its short thick head, long ears, and short mane, while the horse shares its height and body shape. Mules come in all shapes and sizes, influenced largely by their mother. With all the breeds, like quarter horses, draft horses, or shaggy ponies, what kind of mule mix can you imagine? "

data.title: The Abyss Bus Stop - Hermits Rest (Red) Route
data.listingDescription: NO BUS SERVICE during December, January and February. The Abyss shuttle bus stop is outbound only, to Hermits Rest. At the Abyss Overlook, impressive canyon views are rivaled by the 3,000 foot (914 m) vertical drop below you. This stop offers a unique place to discover how gravity can profoundly affect the shape of the canyon walls.

images.altText: A low rock wall separates a bus stop, marked by a red and white sign, from the rim of Grand Canyon.
images.title: The Abyss Shuttle Stop
images.caption: The Abyss features the longest vertical drop from the rim found anywhere along the South Rim.

data.bodyText:
NOT IN SERVICE DURING THE WINTER

Hermit Road is open to private vehicles (under 22 feet) during the months of December, January and Februay, when there is no bus service.

  • Between March 1, and November 30, Hermit Road can only be accessed by the free Hermits Rest (Red) Route shuttle bus, on foot, bicycle, or by commercial tour.

ONE WAY STOP - Outbound Only to Hermits Rest


At the Abyss, impressive canyon views are rivaled by the sheer vertical drop below, the longest such drop found anywhere along the South Rim, 3,000 feet (914 m).

This stop offers a unique place to discover how gravity can profoundly affect the shape of the canyon walls. At The Abyss, no fault line is present, meaning very little water runs into the canyon because it mostly drains to the south away from the rim.

This is unlike many of the other side canyons, which are usually caused by faults cutting through the rock walls and funneling water toward the Colorado River below. Instead, most of the erosion near The Abyss occurs because of gravity's constant pull on the rock face. While at The Abyss, notice the debris of white rocks littered over the red slopes below, showing the evidence of past rock falls.

data.title: The Lookout
data.listingDescription: Designed in 1914, Lookout Studio was Mary Jane Colter's vision to create opportunities for visitors to safely view and photograph the natural beauty of Grand Canyon from its edge. Just west of El Tovar Hotel, "The Lookout" is a neat, comfortable, and rustic studio of stone and log timbers.

images.altText: Lookout Studio on the edge of the canyon with wayside about the building and blue sunny sky
images.caption: Gaze upon the Historical Lookout Studio with the coin operated scopes

data.bodyText: Designed in 1914, Lookout Studio was Mary Jane Colter's vision to create opportunities for visitors to safely view and photograph the natural beauty of Grand Canyon from its edge. Just west of El Tovar Hotel, "The Lookout" is a neat, comfortable, and rustic studio of stone and log timbers.
data.audioDescription:
About 100 feet (30 m) east of Lookout Studio along the Rim Trail, a sepia tone photograph of Lookout Studio fills the left side of a three-foot (1 m) tall angled metal wayside panel. A woman in a long black dress stands midway on the steps leading down from the upper terrace, above a man wearing a suit and bowler hat on the terrace below. Text at the top right of the panel reads:
"The Lookout
Constructed of locally quarried Kaibab limestone, Lookout Studio appears as if it grew out of the canyon wall. In 1914, Fred Harvey company took a bold step to compete against Kolb Studio (just west of here). They asked Mary Colter to design a building on the promontory in front of you, to lure visitors away from the competition. Colter did just that, creating an organic design, which captivated visitors and integrated into the natural surroundings. Can you tell where Colter's walls end and the canyon walls begin?"
A quote from a 1915 Lookout Studio brochure continues:
"A tiny rustic club is The Lookout with its bright hued Navajo rugs, electric lights, cozy fireplace and many easy chairs."
Text at the lower left reads:
""The Lookout," as originally named, was designed as a leisurely space for visitors to gaze upon the canyon and purchase souvenir photos and postcards."
A black-and-white photograph at the lower right shows two women in long coats and wide-brimmed hats standing in bright sunlight looking at a set of rolled architectural drawings. A caption reads:
"Mary Elizabeth Jane Colter (right) designed the Hopi House in 1905, and Hermits Rest and Lookout Studio in 1914. Colter captured the "taste and charm" Fred Harvey company and Santa Fe Railway sought for their buildings. Her pioneering and distinctive style helped shape the architecture of the Southwest and the national parks."

data.title: The Meadow
data.listingDescription: The North Rim developed area is CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. As you passed through Kaibab National Forest and entered the North Rim of Grand Canyon National Park, you probably noticed something unusual. On either side of you, tall and densely clustered pine or aspen trees abruptly end at the edges of this large meadow. Learn why these vibrant forests suddenly stop invading an open, rolling grassy landscape?

images.altText: a small herd of a dozen bison are grazing on the edge of a forest with yellow aspen trees.
images.title: Bison in meadow on the North Rim
images.caption: Maintain a distance of 100 feet (30 meters) from bison. View from inside your vehicle.

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the lodge, visitor center, and campground are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

As you passed through Kaibab National Forest and entered the North Rim of Grand Canyon National Park, you probably noticed something unusual. On either side of you, tall and densely clustered pine or aspen trees abruptly end at the edges of this large meadow. The open area that you see extends for miles.

Why would these vibrant forests suddenly stop invading an open, rolling grassy landscape? Several factors are linked to this phenomenon.

Wildfire has certainly played a role.

Drainage is also a limiting factor. Trees are skilled at soaking up water, though seedlings may have a hard time growing in locations exposed to greater amounts of sun, rain, and snow.

Soil chemistry is also a consideration. Natural toxins and higher alkaline concentrations can prevent the growth of woody plants.

Competition is significant. For example, Ponderosa pine trees struggle to grow in areas dominated by established grasses. Variations in bedrock (primarily Kaibab limestone) may also affect how deep or suitable an area is for seedling growth. And grazing wildlife, like mule deer and bison, keep vegetation low and trimmed.

You can also observe this phenomenon along the beginning of Cape Royal Road, here on the North Rim.

Bison Safety

  • Bison are wild animals and are unpredictable.
  • Maintain a distance of 100 feet (30 m) from bison.
  • When the bison are within 100 feet (30 m) of the road, it is recommended to view wildlife from inside a vehicle.
  • Please use established gravel or paved pull-outs to park vehicles completely off the roadway (all wheels right of the white line). Do not walk or park in the road.

data.title: Thunderbird Lodge
data.listingDescription: Thunderbird Lodge has a contemporary feel, blended with natural touches. Family-focused, many of the rooms here offer canyon views while others overlook Historic Village streets.

images.altText: a contemporary two-story building of beige bricks. A wood registration sign. is in the foreground.
images.title: Thunderbird Lodge with registration sign
images.caption: Registration for Thunderbird Lodge is located at Bright Angel Lodge next door.

data.bodyText:
Thunderbird Lodge has a contemporary feel, blended with natural touches. Family-focused, many of the rooms here offer canyon views while others overlook Historic Village streets. Next door to Kachina, Thunderbird Lodge is also within close proximity to many sites of interest.

Accommodations

Situated directly on the canyon rim, many of the rooms at Thunderbird Lodge have partial canyon views available, called canyon-side rooms. The rooms have either one king bed or two queen beds. Guest room amenities include full bath, in-room Keurig coffee maker, refrigerator, flat screen television with satellite TV, telephone, hairdryer and safe.

Thunderbird Lodge offers accessible rooms. To see available ADA-compliant rooms check the "ADA/Accessible Rooms" box in the online reservations application or call Central Reservations (7a-7p MT) at (888) 297-2757.

Lodging and Contact Info

For day-of check-in and availability information at Kachina Lodge, check with staff at the El Tovar Hotel lobby desk.

For day-of check-in and availability information at Thunderbird Lodge, check in with staff at the Bright Angel Lodge lobby desk.

Call 928-638-2631 to speak to a representative for Xanterra Lodging.

For advance reservations, which are recommended for all holidays and throughout the summer, visit www.grandcanyonlodges.com or call toll-free within the US 888-297-2757. For those outside the US call 303-297-2757.

Architecture and History

Architecturally efficient and rectilinear, both the Kachina and Thunderbird lodges were built as part of a 10-year National Park Service program known as Mission 66. Initiated in 1956, the program intended to diminish the impact of visitor accommodations on sensitive areas near park attractions.

The coloring of the facades of the two-story concrete structures match the immediate canyon rim below, minimizing visibility while the stair-stepped design mimics the patterns seen in the canyon walls itself.

Ideally located, these lodges are situated right along the rim of Grand Canyon, just west of El Tovar Hotel.
data.audioDescription: Architecturally efficient and rectilinear, Thunderbird lodge was built as part of a ten-year National Park Service program known as Mission 66. The coloring of the façade of this two-story concrete structure blends in with the immediate canyon rim below, minimizing the visibility of the lodge. The lodge is ideally located, just down the hill from the El Tovar Hotel, and right along the rim of Grand Canyon.

data.title: Trail of Time: Headquarters Portal (Parking Lot A)
data.listingDescription: To get to this portal, walk the spur trail from near Park Headquarters and parking lot A. It is a 0.4 mile (0.65 km) to the portal at the junction with the Canyon Rim Trail, (Trail of Time). This portal sits at 1,000 million (1 billion) years ago along the Trail of Time, a period of Grand Canyon history which corresponds with the deposition of rocks belonging to the Grand Canyon Supergroup, some of Grand Canyon's oldest sedimentary rocks.

images.altText: paved footpath with a stone portal sign showing canyon rock layers. Canyon landscape in the distance
images.title: Trail of Time - Park Headquarters Portal
images.caption: This Trail of Time portal appears after walking the 0.4 mile spur trail from Park HQ to the rim.

data.bodyText:
To get to this portal, walk the spur trail near Park Headquarters and parking lot A. It is a 0.4 mile (0.65 km) to the portal at the junction with the Canyon Rim Trail, (Trail of Time). 

This portal sits at 1,000 million (1 billion) years ago along the Trail of Time, a period of Grand Canyon history which corresponds with the deposition of rocks belonging to the Grand Canyon Supergroup, some of Grand Canyon's oldest sedimentary rocks.

This fact is reflected in the seating rocks and paving stones surrounding the portal. The paving stones represent sandstones of the Dox Formation, while the seating rocks include several large pieces of Hotauta Conglomerate (the basal member of the Bass Formation) and Bass Limestone; one piece of purplish limestone bears striking ripple marks formed by flowing water.

On the east side of the actual trail junction sits a large piece of Shinumo Quartzite, with an equally large piece of Sixtymile Conglomerate sitting next to it.

Directly opposite these rocks, on the west side of the junction, sit two large stromatolite fossils, the top sides of which have been cut and polished.

Walking west from here will take you to exhibits of the oldest rocks in Grand Canyon and Grand Canyon Village. 0.6 mile (0.9 km).

Walking east from here will take you through Grand Canyon's younger years to the present day and eventually to Yavapai Geology Museum. 0.7 mile (1.13 km).

Trail of Time Overview

The Trail of Time is the world's largest geoscience exhibition at one of the world's grandest geologic landscapes, Grand Canyon National Park. The trail utilizes the unique vistas and rocks of Grand Canyon to help visitors ponder, explore, and understand the magnitude of geologic time and the stories encoded by Grand Canyon rocks and landscapes. Geologic time is immensely long. The 4.56 km (2.8 mi) trail is marked every meter, with 1 meter = 1 million years of our 4,560,000,000 year-long Earth history. Viewing tubes, rocks on plinths, and wayside panels help visitors connect the rocks visible in Grand Canyon to their place along the timeline.

The main Trail of Time can be entered at different points - including the east end near Yavapai Point (young end), west end at Grand Canyon Village (old end), or a middle point where a connecting trail comes from the Park Headquarters parking area (Parking Lot A). Shuttle stops connect each entry point, so you can walk it in several ways and still get back to your car. The entry portals have messages on each side appropriate for those approaching (welcome) or for those completing different segments of the Trail (congratulations).

Located on the South Rim of Grand Canyon National Park, the Trail of Time extends along the paved Rim Trail between the Yavapai Geology Museum on the east and Maricopa Point on the west. The main portion of the Trail between Yavapai Geology Museum and Grand Canyon Village is accessible to wheelchairs and baby strollers, and it is convenient to shuttle bus stops and parking areas in a heavily-visited section of the park.
data.audioDescription: The Trail of Time is a 3.1 mile (5 km) wheelchair accessible interactive trail that winds along the rim on a wide, relatively level paved surface. Along the side of the trail, low concrete pedestals display actual Grand Canyon rocks in a timeline of the canyon's geologic history. Bronze markers embedded in the sidewalk indicate at what point in time you are standing. At the intersection of the trail leading from the park headquarters to the Rim Trail, a six-foot (2 m) tall by four-foot (1.2 m) wide V-shaped rock column shows Grand Canyon's actual rock layers, brought up from deep in the canyon. Touch the column to feel the layers: the oldest black Vishnu Schist and other basement rocks at the bottom, topped by multi-colored diagonal layers of the Grand Canyon Supergroup, followed by more horizontal layers of rock with the Kaibab Formation at the top. Text on the south side of a three-foot (1 m) tall by two-foot (60 cm) wide panel embedded in the column reads: "Welcome to the Trail of Time, a geology timeline. Walk 2 billion years of Grand Canyon history." See and touch samples of Grand Canyon rocks. Discover their ages! Go left to see Grand Canyon's oldest rocks. Go right to walk towards the present. An illustration at the bottom of the panel shows three people on the trail underneath a map of the Trail of Time along the rim of Grand Canyon. Text reads: "One long step = 1 million years." A highlighted marker at their feet reads "1,000 million years ago." In the center of the panel, a map shows the route of the Trail of Time along the rim. Text in a yellow box at the right of the map reads, "You Are Here," indicating a point on the trail about halfway between the Village in the center and Yavapai Geology Museum at the right. Maricopa Point is at the far left, to the west. The map shows shuttle bus stops and parking lot locations, and the locations of several restrooms. At the top of the map, small bits of blue show the Colorado River flowing at the bottom of the canyon. Text on the opposite north side of the panel reads: "You are leaving the Trail of Time, a geology timeline! Come back and walk the rest of the Trail of Time on your next visit." An illustration at the bottom of the panel underneath the same map shows an empty trail.

data.bodyText:
From the flagpole outside of Verkamp's Visitor Center, walk to the right along the rim trail and find the Trail of Time bronze markers embedded in the pavement. From the 2,000 million year marker, you can see the western entry portal for the Trail of Time. Walking east from Grand Canyon Village takes you forward in time, from Grand Canyon's oldest rocks to canyon carving and Grand Canyon's human history.

This is the "old" end of the main Trail of Time, so the theme for the paving stones and seating rocks around the portal is Precambrian schist and gneiss of the type found in the inner gorges, near the bottom of the canyon. Walk a bit further east along the trail and you can see and touch the oldest known rock of Grand Canyon's basement rocks!

Along the side of the trail, low concrete pedestals display actual Grand Canyon rocks in a timeline of the canyon's geologic history. Bronze markers embedded in the sidewalk indicate at what point in time you are standing. Moving along the trail from Verkamp's Visitor Center, a six-foot (2 m) tall by four-foot (1.2 m) wide V-shaped rock column shows Grand Canyon's actual rock layers, brought up from deep in the canyon. Touch the column to feel the layers: the oldest black Vishnu Schist and other basement rocks at the bottom, topped by multi-colored diagonal layers of the Grand Canyon Supergroup, followed by more horizontal layers of rock with the Kaibab Formation at the top. Text on the west side of a three-foot (1 m) tall by two-foot (60 cm) wide panel embedded in the column reads: "Welcome to the Trail of Time, a geology timeline. Walk 2 billion years of Grand Canyon history. See and touch samples of Grand Canyon Rocks. Discover their ages!" An illustration at the bottom of the panel shows an older couple walking along the trail next to a woman and her young son. Text reads: "One long step = 1 million years." A highlighted marker at their feet reads: "1,970 million years ago." In the center of the panel, a map shows the route of the Trail of Time along the rim. Text in a yellow box in the middle of the map reads, "You Are Here," pointing to the trail behind the Verkamp's Visitor Center, next to other buildings in the Village. You have just walked the Trail of Time, a geology timeline covering 2 billion years of Grand Canyon history." Continue through the Village to Maricopa Point (2.5 km, 1.5 mi.) to the age of the Earth. An illustration at the bottom of the panel underneath the same map shows a man and woman looking west over the canyon toward Maricopa Point.

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No eating or open drink containers.

  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).

  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.

  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.

  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.

  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.

data.title: Trailview Overlook Bus Stop - Hermits Rest (Red) Route
data.listingDescription: A short walk down the stairs from the parking/shuttle stop is the best location for aerial views of the sinuous switchbacks on Bright Angel Trail. From the viewpoint you can see everything from where the trail starts just west of the historic village down, and down, and down to Havasupai Gardens, until the trail finally disappears into the depths of the inner gorge. —NO BUS SERVICE during December, January and February.

images.altText: A couple sits on a rock wall along the rim of Grand Canyon next to a shuttle stop with a red sign.
images.title: Trailview Overlook Shuttle Stop
images.caption: Walking down the stairs from the shuttle stop gives excellent views of the Bright Angel Trail.

data.bodyText:
NOT IN SERVICE DURING THE WINTER

Hermit Road is open to private vehicles (under 22 feet) during the months of December, January and Februay, when there is no bus service.

  • Between March 1, and November 30, Hermit Road can only be accessed by the free Hermits Rest (Red) Route shuttle bus, on foot, bicycle, or by commercial tour.


This stop is outbound only - to Hermits Rest

Nearby:

  • Canyon Overlook
  • Canyon Rim Trail access

A short walk down the stairs from the shuttle stop is the best location for aerial views of the sinuous switchbacks of Bright Angel Trail. From this viewpoint, you can see everything —from where the trial starts just west of the historic village, down, and down, 3000 feet (914 m) to Havasupai Garden, until the trail finally disappears into the depths of the inner gorge.

Looking south and southeast you can see the Historic District of Grand Canyon Village, a collection of hotels and visitor services that has retained much of its orignial character from the early 20th Century.  Further to the south, the hazy blue mountains of the San Francisco Volcanic Field rise above the Coconino Plateau to dot the horizon, with the snow-capped San Francisco Peaks towering the highest.

From this overlook, you can walk downhill along the Canyon Rim Trail, 0.7 miles (1.1 km) and return to the village. 

Hermits Rest (Red) Route 

Tentative Spring 2026 Schedule - Starting March 1
80 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)
 
  • First bus leaves Hermit Transfer Station at 8:00 am. 
  • Buses run every 10-15 minutes.
  • Last bus - one hour after sunset.
  • Be at a bus stop 30 minutes after sunset

Route Information

If you simply ride this shuttle bus without getting off at any stop, the entire loop will take approximately 80 minutes to return to where you started.

From the Trailview Overlook shuttle stop, buses only travel outbound (westbound) towards Hermits Rest, stopping at the following locations. 

 

  • Maricopa Point

  • Powell Point (Outbound)

  • Hopi Point

  • Mohave Point (Outbound)

  • The Abyss

  • Monument Creek Vista

  • Pima Point (Outbound)

  • Hermits Rest

The buses turn around at Hermits Rest, then return inbound (eastbound) to the Village, stopping only at the following locations:

  • Pima Point (Inbound)
  • Mohave Point (Inbound)
  • Powell Point (Inbound)
  • Village Route Transfer

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No eating or open drink containers.
     

  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).

  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.

  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.

  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.

  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.
data.audioDescription: From the Trailview Overlook shuttle bus stop, two ramps lead north through the low limestone wall lining the sidewalk. A couple wooden benches sit on a flat, pebbly area on the other side of the wall between the two entrance points, across some low limestone boulders lining the asphalt path. Ten feet (3 m) to the east of a vertical wayside panel with an eight-foot (2.4 m) wide limestone base, a long set of concrete stairs, four-feet (1.2 m) wide with metal handrails on both sides, leads down to an overlook. Move 16 steps down to a concrete sidewalk. Follow 20 feet (6 m) along the right handrail to two more steps, then continue 20 feet (6 m) forward to where another set of stairs leads down to the right with handrails on both sides. Follow along the right handrail to move down a series of staircases and landings down a total of 54 stairs to an asphalt-paved path. Turn left and continue 25 feet (8 m) along the handrail at your right to an overlook area ringed by a four-foot (1.2 m) high metal railing. At the left, text on a three-foot (1 m) tall angled metal wayside panel reads: Breaking Ground Look down Garden Creek Canyon at the winding Bright Angel Trail. The Earth’s crust fractured in this area, lifting one side of the rock layers and lowering the other, creating a fault. The trail follows this fault into the canyon. Water also follows the fault. Springs, like those at Indian Garden, are able to flow because the groundwater has reached impermeable rock, where it spreads out sideways and leaks out of the canyon walls as springs. A picture of the canyon from this vantage point fills the bottom two-thirds of the panel. A thick yellow line in the middle of the panel shows the location of the Bright Angel Fault, running across the bottom of the canyon through Indian Garden all the way across to the North Rim. A circular picture inset at the lower left shows your location as viewed from the North Rim of the canyon. Two cliff faces are highlighted with arrows, one pointing down, the other pointing up. A caption reads: Sixty million years ago the west side of Bright Angel Fault was lifted higher than the east side.
